content: maybe we can have a discussion about this here
I've talked with @nikomatsakis about this a while ago
@nikomatsakis going to paste what I could find searching ...

Might though has always been:
relevant to team members -> forge
relevant to random contributors -> guide

nikomatsakis: I'm in favor of forge for documenting "team procedure"
nikomatsakis: rustc-guide for explaining how rustc works
nikomatsakis: some of these things are kind of in the middle so they could probably go either place but
nikomatsakis: if they go on forge, I think we should link to them aggressively from rustc-guide
nikomatsakis: e.g., if we are walking through an average contribution, we might also kick off the section -- and end it -- with links to the forge
nikomatsakis: and vice versa if we opted for rustc-guide
but I guess the most important thing is I think rustc-dev-guide should be just about explaining how rustc works
I agree with what Niko have said, I'm a little bit less certain about what exactly belongs in forge
yeah, like, team procedures
but what else exactly?
also ... we have ICE-breakers in rustc-guide, I don't think that should go there
it's not about explaining how rustc works
Yeah, we also have info about what the t-compiler is
what I'd do is have in rustc-dev-guide a contributing to rust section that explains some ways to join and link to these procedures that maybe live in forge
and how to stabilize features

mark-i-m said:

Yeah, we also have info about what the t-compiler is

exactly, these things don't go in rustc-dev-guide in my opinion
or forge or compiler-team repo I'd say
I guess I disagree
I feel like that's the sort of info about "how things work" that is useful to contributors
It doesn't need to be in detail, but it should explain how to do stuff that contributors normally need to do
I would argue that interacting with t-compiler or stabilizing features is within that scope
in that case we should put a bunch of more things in rustc-dev-guide, like how homu, bors and a bunch of other things work
am with @Santiago Pastorino here... dev-guide could get sprawling (and already is)
I was trying to read the rustc-dev-guide slowly kind of from cover to cover
I like niko comment that we can follow option of linking aggressively
and I think we could make somethings that looks more like a book
which you can actually read from cover to cover in order to understand how the compiler works
and a lot of procedures and things like that I think doesn't help if we try to accomplish something like that
agreed
hmm... I guess I've always though more of the guide as a reference document than a book... a contributor's one-stop shopping for anything they could possibly need to know
well we may always move certain things to appendices or something and still making them look like a book or something readable from beginning to end

mark-i-m said:

hmm... I guess I've always though more of the guide as a reference document than a book... a contributor's one-stop shopping for anything they could possibly need to know

well there are some parts that are like that, but once you jump into how the compiler works it may make sense to do from beginning to end
all the new organization that mainly you've layed out also helps in that regard in my opinion
from part 2 on is waaay more readable
anyway, I guess this goes back to maybe defining a bit better what do we think is the purpose of the guide

mark-i-m said:

hmm... I guess I've always though more of the guide as a reference document than a book... a contributor's one-stop shopping for anything they could possibly need to know

I think at some point that was my expectation, then I found out about forge
also, who maintains the forge?
one thing that seems clear to me is that we could tidy up things a bit better between what's in compiler-team, forge and rustc-dev-guide

Tshepang Lekhonkhobe said:

also, who maintains the forge?

doesn't seem to have its own wg
no, i think it is mostly maintained by the infra and release teams
as most of the things in there are relevant to them iirc
yeah, it's more something that is cross team relevant I also guess
another possibility is to leave rustc-dev-guide without these procedures and things and move all that stuff to compiler-team

so here is another idea:
what if we split the guide into 2 halves: first half reads more like a book and the second half is more of a reference
although, I can see the second half getting messy fast
yeah that's also a possibility
I'd say, let's defer this decision until we lay out some organization ideas in the document
I guess with concrete stuff things will be more clear
I updated the doc (https://hackmd.io/5BnDamiMSFOO8A_S5xggYQ) with what I'm thinking. Let me know what you think
Did anyone have thoughts about ^^^?

Also, there seems to be a general feeling (that I am willing to go along with) that we should try to move stuff out of the guide (see also https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/131828-t-compiler/topic/forge.20vs.20compiler-team.20vs.20rustc-dev-guide)
@mark-i-m I think I'd try to sketch a solution for this, maybe next week I have time to dive into it
like propose some changes and talk over concrete things
what do you think? if you want we can coordinate and do this together
@Santiago Pastorino sure, I'm curious to see what your thinking of
@mark-i-m do you want to schedule something on the calendar to go over this together?
if so, could be next week
Sure, we can do that
Next week works for me
(lol, perhaps we should have kept the 2-week meetings :P)
Oh, now I'm remembering the conversation! sorry!
Perhaps we can go through the above and linked HackMD and propose something?
Hi @Santiago Pastorino :)
hi
ready?
yes
so how do you want to approach this?
I was starting to read some of the things we've discussed
let me read this https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/131828-t-compiler/topic/forge.20vs.20compiler-team.20vs.20rustc-dev-guide first
sure, perhaps we can collect the links in the hackmd?
https://hackmd.io/5BnDamiMSFOO8A_S5xggYQ?both
ok back
so I guess the main thing we need to define first is:
what belongs to forge, what belongs to compiler-team and what belongs to rustc-dev-guide
I meant, where is exactly the line
perhaps we can start with a related question: what is the expected audience of each resource?
some of the thoughts I've read on that topic seem to point more or less in the following direction ...

forge: documenting team procedures
rustc-dev-guide: explaining how rustc works
compiler-team: things that are not procedures, getting involved and stuff like that

mark-i-m said:

perhaps we can start with a related question: what is the expected audience of each resource?

yes, this is also a good question
also, in the thread people were saying that maybe compiler-team should be deprecated in favor of forge
I think an approach I like is:
1. leave forge as documentation of procedures in general and compiler in particular, and with that reasoning we should move some stuff from compiler-team and rustc-dev-guide to forge

1. leave compiler-team for contributing and getting involved like information. So we may also move some rustc-dev-guide there and from rustc-dev-guide we can keep that information shorter and link there.

at least this as a first step and if we want to deprecate compiler-team in favor of forge we can do it as a second step but would be better to first come up with something that looks a bit better and organized and then it will be easier to see what makes most sense
1. leave rustc-dev-guide as how rustc works in general, so we would be moving what I've mentioned in 1 and 2
this would be my high level idea of this
@mark-i-m what do you think?

just so we are on the same page, I guess in my mind I've always broken it down as follows:

  • forge: primary audience is t-release/t-infra, so it contains things they need, and nobody else really goes there
  • rustc-dev-guide: audience is contributors to rustc and std/core/alloc, and should make it as easy as possible for new comers
  • compiler-team: primarily for the t-compiler to self-organize. Most people don't go there/don't know it exists. And TBH, I don't really know why it exists either?
But I feel like the audience question needs to be central. Otherwise, what are we optimizing for?
:+1:
so I see where we differ here
my understanding of forge originally was exactly the same as yours
but I think that idea has changed

Welcome to the Rust Forge! Rust Forge serves as a repository of supplementary documentation useful for members of The Rust Programming Language. If you find any mistakes, typos, or want to add to the Rust Forge, feel free to file an issue or PR on the Rust Forge GitHub.
and also ...
there's a full compiler section there
https://forge.rust-lang.org/compiler/index.html
forge right now is more like a general procedures site about all the teams
there's cross-compilation, review policies about prs
is that what we want it to be?
and things like that
i.e. should we move more in that direction by moving stuff from the guide?
unsure who is we ? :)
I personally would answer yes to both questions
and my guess seeing the content we have on forge and some of the things that @pnkfelix and nikomatsakis have done and said, I guess that's what we want

Santiago Pastorino said:

unsure who is we ? :)

that's also a great question? i would say perhaps "the rust teams in general"? but especially wg-rustc-dev-guide, since we would be moving some of our stuff there
i.e. would the wg be taking on responsibility for some of the content on the forge?
I don't think so
I think the procedures we have on the guide that would be moved there would end being maintained by all of us
well in some senses the same applies to the guide :)
I see
we should all be responsible for it
but if we take a look at forge is clearly about procedures
including compiler procedures
like even reviewing
so I'd say stabilizing goes there
and other things like
https://rust-lang.github.io/compiler-team/procedures/crates/
Hmm... but all of the procedures I see there are ones that tend to be done by team members, right?
what do you mean exactly?
procedures on forge?
yes
you're saying that procedures on forge are mainly about things that members do?

Santiago Pastorino said:

https://rust-lang.github.io/compiler-team/procedures/crates/

I think I agree that this should go in the forge instead

Santiago Pastorino said:

you're saying that procedures on forge are mainly about things that members do?

yes, that's my impression
but I think it may be room for things that can be done by members and non-members too
I'm more and more starting to be convinced about ...

Santiago Pastorino said:

forge: documenting team procedures
rustc-dev-guide: explaining how rustc works
compiler-team: things that are not procedures, getting involved and stuff like that

:point_up:
at least to try to come up with PRs and discuss it with concrete changes
but an average contributor wouldn't go to the forge for much currently, right? so we would be changing that. Or am I misunderstanding you?
I think as a contributor you would go to rustc-dev-guide to understand how the compiler works and then search for more stuff elsewhere
like even coming to Zulip
and also, a contributor would quickly need to know about bors, homu, etc and you'll need to find that on forge anyway
I guess I still keep coming back to the same audience question: I feel it would not be good to mix what the compiler team needs and what a random contributor needs...
e.g. I don't think I have ever read the bors/homu forge page
I just figured it out from watching github
I think as a contributor you would go to rustc-dev-guide to understand how the compiler works and then search for more stuff elsewhere
I think, this is actually something I don't want.
In particular, the "searching for stuff elsewhere" is very frustrating as an outsider
I understand your point and I see how are you looking at this issue
because I don't know where stuff will be. It can be in a billion different places
yeah, so, I said a confusing phrase there
I think we should link from the guide elsewhere
when needed
of course that makes a lot of sense
so I guess we are seeing this issue from different angles
if I'm understanding correctly you're more on the let's have all the contributing material on rustc-dev-guide
and I'm more about trying to give more cohesion to our materials :)
Hmm yes
unsure what to do with that :)
And there seems to be a tradeoff:
have a lot of really focused resources
or have one big "everything is here" doc
yes BUT

mark-i-m said:

have a lot of really focused resources

disagree with this
I wouldn't want to have a lot of really focused resources
it's just 2 resources
rustc-dev-guide and forge
right now I think our materials are a bit messy
well, 3 if we have compiler-team
but we also have gh, discord, zulip
which are kind of resources too
yeah but compiler-team could even be deprecated in favor of forge and it exist anyway
perhaps that's not the same thing, but I think it adds to my sense of too many sources of info
Sure, so I think we agree on that
So we should focus on forge vs guide and not move anything else to compiler-team?
so my ideal final pictures is, a more focused on let's learn about how rustc works in rustc-dev-guide and that guide can also talk about contributing, getting involved, but that's not the focus
it should even mention forge and link to it
so what I'm suggesting is more general info about procedures and links to forge
Can you talk a bit more about what level of detail would be in the guide?
then forge having the rest of the procedures and also the getting involved sections

mark-i-m said:

Can you talk a bit more about what level of detail would be in the guide?

I wouldn't change it that much to be honest
let me check
e.g. would it be a part 1 (like we have now) but stripped down?
yeah, mainly remove things from part 1
move those to forge
not all of them
let me check
in that case, it might make sense to have a new forge section specifically for contributors
maybe yes
but specifically
would move this one https://rustc-dev-guide.rust-lang.org/stabilization_guide.html out
this one https://rustc-dev-guide.rust-lang.org/stability.html maybe not but maybe we want that in a different part of the guide
unsure
was looking at https://rustc-dev-guide.rust-lang.org/conventions.html
stabilization is an interesting example, because it was one of the first things I moved from the forge to the guide
so to be honest I'm not 100% sure what to do with those
it may be on an appendix
what I don't want these things is to be so central
or perhaps the problem is that those sections discuss places were the code and the procedures interact
it's one of the first things you read in the guide
Question: so what about the chapters about how to build the compiler?
Or how to debug?
we should keep those
They are more of reference material... i.e. probably not something you would want to read through, but definitely useful
yes
So at the bottom of this doc: https://hackmd.io/5BnDamiMSFOO8A_S5xggYQ?both
I had made a proposal where I split part 1 into two appendix-like parts
"Building and Debugging" and "Contributing to rustc"
Perhaps it make sense to move the latter into the forge and keep the former as a last Reference part of the guide
so yeah I like this a bit better
unsure if building and debugging needs to be an appendix, it can be a full normal section
but I think it's better at the end
I guess if we are working towards a guide that one would just read beginning to end, it seems hard to make it a normal section
with the proposed structure I'm 99% fine :)
(e.g. I would find it very boring)
let me update the hackmd with the proposal
@mark-i-m should we remove the move to forge section?
well I'm not sure if all that stuff is something we wanted to do
I think we can keep it while we are plannign
:+1:
so we can easily move stuff around
@Santiago Pastorino So if we agree on this rough proposed structure, perhaps we can now discuss some more of the details?
yeah
also, I think in this version, I have moved some other stuff around... not 100% sure
so if we start with this proposed structure
I think we need something before High-level Compiler Architecture
some sort of intro?
yes
maybe some sort of intro
maybe that's also merged with about this guide
something that explains what's the guide about
encourage to contribute
Hmm... we already have such a section?
explain where to find stuff
https://rustc-dev-guide.rust-lang.org/about-this-guide.html
We could expand this ^^^
yes
well maybe it's just that plus some links to contributing?
:+1:
unsure
And this is where we would link to forge?
yes
something like that is what I'd do
not just saying
Forge -- contains documentation about rust infrastructure, team procedures, and more
Right
but linking specifically to some of the things we may want to move out
if we do
maybe it's something like Getting Started
Question: what about the "walkthrough: a typical contribution" section?
which starts with that about section or something
so what I think is a Getting Started section may have most of the stuff we already have in part 1
but in a reduced form
like, it's important to show how to build
how to test
how to open a PR
but maybe, the stages explanations about building and all our deep building sections may go later in the guide
also, some that Getting Started may have a contributing section or something like that that points to forge
sure, we could have the most common 1 or 2 commands/workflows and just point to the other part
exactly
@mark-i-m we are more or less on time
wondering what should we do now :)
I can keep going if you have time
let's keep it going for a while then
I'm just updating the hackmd to keep track
to reduce a bit the scope of our first steps I'd try to come up with a better organization for rustc-dev-guide first
and maybe move some things to appendices
we can just focus on that
:+1:
once we have a better idea of what we want to do we may just say ... hey appendix W would look better on forge
Sure
let's do that then
Sure, shall we go through the proposed outline chapter by chapter?
so we are kind of doing what we were supposed to do since a while which is define the structure of the guide :joy:

mark-i-m said:

Sure, shall we go through the proposed outline chapter by chapter?

let me check again the proposed structure
do you think it worth doing that? or just check part one plus this getting started idea?
I guess I mildly prefer the proposal since there is already a bit of organization there
We can start with the "move to forge" section and decide if we want to move to forge or move to appendix instead?
Then go through the chapters at the end of the proposal and the appendices
I think we misunderstood each other here :)
anyway
yes, we should go over the proposal for sure, I didn't mean to say something different
do you mean now or later?

mark-i-m said:

We can start with the "move to forge" section and decide if we want to move to forge or move to appendix instead?

I'd say, let's start moving all that to appendix as we've said and leave the forge idea for the future

mark-i-m said:

do you mean now or later?

let's do it now
if you have time
sure
works for me
ok is looking good :)
There are two more sections I would propose we move to the appendix
"Distribution artifacts"
and "Documenting Compiler"
Most people don't need to do those.
:+1:
as you've done, let's for now leave a comment for future reference
you convinced me to not move to forge, now you want to move things to forge? :P :P :P
Oh, should I move them in the proposal?
Lol, you've convinced me to move, now you want to not move :P
would be great if we end this meeting with you convinced to move to forge and me to not move to forge :joy:

mark-i-m said:

Lol, you've convinced me to move, now you want to not move :P

LOL, I seem to be playing a social experiment now :P
:rofl:
seriously, I want to move things to forge, all I'm saying is let's just note this stuff there and not make decisions now
Lol, I think we are starting to come to a bit more consensus though
Agreed
what I meant to do is to break a bit what we are trying to do into some steps
because we seem to be doing quite a lot with one shoot

mark-i-m said:

Lol, I think we are starting to come to a bit more consensus though

definitely
let's talk about Getting Started
I was thinking about it for a bit like
Getting Started (AKA getting started to contribute to Rustc)
like to me this guide is about, we want you to learn rustc so you can contribute to it
yes, with some handy tips for working with the compiler source code
e.g. how to build, debug, profile
yeah there should go all the setups, preparations, etc
most programming languages book start with installing the language, setting up the editor, links to things that may be useful and things like that
a little section about editors, or settings or things may be nice
config.toml
right now I don't remember what do we already have in the guide :)
We do have that content in part 1
but we also have a lot of other stuff
ok
yeah
what do you think of the "building and debugging rustc" section in the proposal
is that what you are thinking?
I was thinking that that section could be just build with most of what's there
and mainly some todo parts
Do you mean that we would move it to the beginning again?

mark-i-m said:

what do you think of the "building and debugging rustc" section in the proposal

let me check again
oh, i misunderstood

mark-i-m said:

Do you mean that we would move it to the beginning again?

no no, I was talking about the getting started, let me check debugging
Why don't we have a :race_condition: emoji?
hehehe :)
:race:
about debugging I'm not sure yet, I don't love where it is right now but I don't have better ideas for now
the "building and debugging" section seems like too much imho
yeah, that's what I meant
the rest of the guide is looking better but that section is not great currently
hmm... i have a few ideas but not really clear
yeah me too
so I think that we can try to break that section up
that's what I was going to say
first of all unsure if I like all that together
the very minimum split I'd do is
building + testing and debugging + profiling
but unsure if I wouldn't break even more

Perhaps for each broken part we can also have an overview that is more readable and a details section that has more reference like info, with a message at the top like "you may want to skip to the next section"
e.g. I think the way we build and the way we test is actually an important and interesting as important/interesting as the structure of the compiler
One question: do you see the "Getting Started" section as a single chapter or multiple chapters?
If we make it multiple chapters, then perhaps it becomes much like the part 1 we already have?
I was thinking more like one chapter
but unsure, what's your idea?
ok, I think we agree on that
so ... I think this is a great first iteration
I think right now it may be hard to continue without just trying to impact those changes
because it may be clear what we've left off
also once we open a PR with this change we can get feedback
I can totally go ahead and cook a PR with this and start discussions based on that
but maybe we can just leave this document here for async discussion with the rest of the working group
Sure this seems like a good starting point
A PR might be the easiest way to organize feedback
but I'm also ok with leaving it in the hackmd for now
@Santiago Pastorino Thanks! I think this has been productive
@mark-i-m thanks to you too

I guess one thing that I think can still be improved is that it would be good to figure out what to do with all the reference-like material, like the detailed notes on building and testing... but we can leave that for later
agreed

@WG-rustc-dev-guide we were supposed to work or forge vs rustc-dev-guide but if you read the backlog the meeting quickly turned into a discussion about the content of rustc-dev-guide and we ended coming up with this https://hackmd.io/5BnDamiMSFOO8A_S5xggYQ?edit
please check it out and let's improve it, I'm going to open a PR about it as soon as we're ok with it
@WG-rustc-dev-guide I wonder if I should just open a PR with these changes or people are reviewing it?
maybe we can review from the PR
sure, if others would find that more useful
just added my thoughts
